story:
This is my story...well this is the story of my daughter. She has Scoliosis. Her name is Kelsi. Now some people think that Scoliosis is not that big of deal, but in some cases, like my daughter, it is huge. My daughter has had Scoliosis since she was fifteen. She is now nineteen.

 

WHAT IS SCOLIOSIS

For anyone that does not know what Scolioisi is, let me try to explain in short term. The vast majority of people with this condition are not expected to require treatment. The problem is we do not know who will get it, why they get it, which will progress, or how far they will progress. Each year scoliosis patients make more than 600,000 visits to private physician offices, and an estimated 30,000 children are put into a brace for scoliosis, while 38,000 patients undergo spinal fusion surgery.  Despite physicians trying to treat this spinal deformity for centuries, 85% of the cases are classified as idiopathic. Consequently, a scoliosis patient's life is exacerbated by many unknowns, and treatments therefore that are often ineffective, invasive, and/or costly. Scoliosis patients also have increased health risks due to frequent x-ray exposure. Scoliosis is a multifactorial disorder, which requires multidisciplinary research and treatment. There is no cure and doctors do not know the cause of it. It is more common in girls then boys. It is a medical condition in which a person's spine is curved from side to side. Although it is a complex three-dimensional deformity, on an X-ray, viewed from the rear, the spine of an individual with scoliosis may look more like an "S" or a "C" than a straight line. Some severe cases of scoliosis can lead to diminishing lung capacity, putting pressure on the heart, and restricting physical activities.

 

KELSI'S STORY

That is where my daughter comes in. Since she was fifteen she has had two surgeries, which for most scoliosis patients, one is rare. The first surgery they put one bar and five screws in her spine to make her spine straight because it was so curved it was effecting her breathing. On that surgery she had slight nerve damage in her right leg and was in a wheel chair for awhile but with hard work and months of physical therapy, came out okay, so we thought. Some of the screws did not want to fuse(stay in the spine and hold the bar into place) so they had to go back in for a second surgery. On this surgery they decided to put two more bars in and 24 more screws into her spine to help hold everything where it was supposed to be. She went thru more physical therapy.

 

YOUR HELP

This is where you come in. Now at nineteen, three bars and 29 screws later and having alot of infections from the bars, she now needs a third surgery!!  Medicine is not working! So they want to go back in and take out some bars and screws and clean out the infection,  still not sure if the infection will continue to spread! We are hopeful that we can hold off until May for her to have the surgery and her family and friends are reaching out to the public to ask for assistance in raising money to help pay for the numerous medical expenses that come along with this.  

You may also make scoliosis more aware to people and visit there web site at: http://www.scoliosis.org

story:
The video shares the combined experiences of children like my daughter who have been adopted after time in foster care or orphanages.

Short Summary

I am a single, working mom with one 12-year-old daughter who came home via adoption about five months ago. She has had a lot of grief and loss issues to work through since arriving -- including having difficult memories triggered from the very distant past. Her therapist and doctors are currently recommending more intensive therapy. Unfortunately, insurance has covered none of her therapy thus far, and the finances are more than I can afford to pay. But, I want her to get the best help that she can to have the most opportunity for healing.


What We Need 

I am hoping to raise $36,000 that will cover about 6 months of therapy for my daughter. This is a program that can range from 12-14 months, and I will try to get the rest by continuing to pester the insurance company and applying for grants and loans. All funds raised will go directly to my daughter's account with the program. 

  • Fees include: Family/group/individual therapy, room and board, round-the-clock monitoring by staff, academics, recreation and therapeutic activities, regular health care and evaluations, hygiene items, etc (all-inclusive pay per day rate)


Other Ways You Can Help

  • Feel free to link to and share this campaign! 
  • Please pray for my daughter and I as both of us work with this program (yes, there are requirements for parents to fulfill as well!), that she will be motivated to find healing. It's going to be a tough process.

story:
CAVELL’S STORY

In 2009, at the age of 29, my friend Cavell Bockting was diagnosed with stage one breast cancer. I was heartbroken, as I watched my childhood friend undergo the long grueling process of a double mastectomy, chemotherapy, and reconstructive surgery. Nevertheless, Cavell was determined and fought ruthlessly against cancer. Even when she knew she was going to lose all of her hair, she didn’t let cancer get the best of her. Cavell bravely had the last laugh by cutting her hair into a Mohawk. Cavell was a fighter and never complained as her friends and family nursed her back to health.

A few years later, with her newfound health, Cavell wanted to fulfill one of her dreams. Leaving her hometown of Arlington, VA, Cavell moved to Denver, Colorado to start a new chapter in her life. Anyone ever affected by disease knows it has the unfortunate ability to constantly remind you life is too short, so live it to the fullest. Once settled, she was preparing to go to school for nursing because Cavell wanted to help other cancer patients win their battles.

This past month, May 15, 2013, Cavell was hit with devastating news once again. Cavell has been diagnosed with lymph node cancer.  On June 10th, Cavell went under the knife again. Thankfully, surgery was successful but Cavell still has a long battle in front of her and I want to help make it as painless as possible.

WHAT SHE NEEDS

I am asking for $5,000 as a starting point to help Cavell during this battle. Cancer is expensive and with her new job, Cavell doesn’t have the sick time or vacation to help her with her recovery. The money raised will go towards mounting medical bills, prescriptions, and of course the much needed blood orange sorbet after chemotherapy. If any money is left over, it will be applied to Cavell’s nursing education.

WHAT YOU GET

If cancer or any other disease has ever affected you or your loved ones, you know the power of the kindness of strangers. You will get the gratification of helping Cavell through her toughest times. Every dollar makes a difference and will help Cavell focus on what is most important, regaining her health.

IMPACT

Anyone that knows Cavell, knows she is an amazing caretaker and a loyal friend.  Nobody deserves to go through this ever, especially twice. Please join me in helping her fight cancer again. Her family needs her, especially her adorable dogs, Remy and Romeo.

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

I know times are tough financially for many people, so I ask that if you can’t donate please spread the word. Thank you all for taking the time to read her story.

Cavell bravely had the last laugh by cutting her hair into a Mohawk. Cavell was a fighter and never complained as her friends and family nursed her back to health.
A few years later, with her newfound health, Cavell wanted to fulfill one of her dreams. Leaving her hometown of Arlington, VA, Cavell moved to Denver, Colorado to start a new chapter in her life. Anyone ever affected by disease knows it has the unfortunate ability to constantly remind you life is too short, so live it to the fullest. Once settled, she was preparing to go to school for nursing because Cavell wanted to help other cancer patients win their battles.
This past month, May 15, 2013, Cavell was hit with devastating news once again. Cavell has been diagnosed with lymph node cancer.  On June 10th, Cavell went under the knife again. Thankfully, surgery was successful but Cavell still has a long battle in front of her and I want to help make it as painless as possible.
WHAT SHE NEEDS
I am asking for $5,000 as a starting point to help Cavell during this battle. Cancer is expensive and with her new job, Cavell doesn’t have the sick time or vacation to help her with her recovery. The money raised will go towards mounting medical bills, prescriptions, and of course the much needed blood orange sorbet after chemotherapy. If any money is left over, it will be applied to Cavell’s nursing education.
WHAT YOU GET
If cancer or any other disease has ever affected you or your loved ones, you know the power of the kindness of strangers. You will get the gratification of helping Cavell through her toughest times. Every dollar makes a difference and will help Cavell focus on what is most important, regaining her health.
IMPACT
Anyone that knows Cavell, knows she is an amazing caretaker and a loyal friend.  Nobody deserves to go through this ever, especially twice. Please join me in helping her fight cancer again. Her family needs her, especially her adorable dogs, Remy and Romeo.
OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP
I know times are tough financially for many people, so I ask that if you can’t donate please spread the word. Thank you all for taking the time to read her story.
